87.50.text:
I`m going to my parents`
for the weekend.

89.44.text:
My sister`s picking me up
at quarter past nine.

93.10.text:
We`re having a big family dinner
on Sunday evening.

97.21.text:
So I`m going straight
into work on Monday.

114.87.text: Who is it What`s he like

117.04.text:
Well, he`s very good-looking
and he`s got lovely eyes.

120.93.text:
What does he do Come on, Julia.
Who is it

123.44.text: He works for a TV company.

127.12.text: In fact, he`s probably on TV right now.

135.13.text:
You`re watching the local
weekend news on Apex TV.

138.23.text: I`m Gary Fenton. It`s nine fifteen.

143.96.text:
Oh, there`s Cindy. Bye, Julia.
See you on Monday.

158.80.text:
On Saturday mornings Charlie and
Molly Craddock usually go shopping...

166.18.text: They`re walking round the local park.

170.76.text:
Molly. Why are you walking
round the park backwards

174.24.text:
We`re collecting money for
local charities.

177.83.text: Not for us, because we practise.

180.08.text:
We walk round our garden
for two hours every day.

184.53.text:
- It`s very easy, you know.
- And it`s great fun. Oh! Oops!

196.84.text: Are you waiting for someone, Tim

200.09.text:
What Oh, yes.
Ah, here she is.

212.85.text:
The police are coming to see us
this afternoon.

215.67.text:
Jason and Kylie put soap powder in the
neighbours` fish pond yesterday.

220.82.text: Well, good luck. We`re going into town.

235.20.text:
She`s going out with someone
and he works here.

252.44.text:
You`ll never guess, but
she`s going out with Gary.

254.07.text:
Nonsense! Julia`s got more
sense than that.

256.76.text: It`s true. She told me on Saturday.

260.92.text: What time am I meeting Frederick today

262.76.text:
Oh, he phoned to say
that he can`t make it.

264.53.text:
Could you call him on his mobile
He`s at the House of Commons.

288.12.text:
Julia, are you doing anything
this evening

291.99.text: Yes, I am. I`m going out.

294.39.text: Are you going out tomorrow, too

296.46.text:
No, I`m not. I`m staying in and
watching a video with Rebecca.

303.83.text:
Look. What is this, Gary
What do you want

306.57.text:
Oh, come on, Julia. Don`t be shy.
I know your little secret.

332.29.text:
How was your weekend
at your parents

336.70.text:
They argued all the time and
I got the usual lecture.

339.57.text:
"Why don`t you get a proper job like
Cindy She`s doing so well."

345.51.text:
Well, on Saturday morning
I was with Tim in Wrigley Park.

351.31.text:
Yes, they do. Well, I can`t stay
here all day.

354.55.text:
And then Julia arrived and
she and Tim...

359.02.text:
Yeah, it seems they`re going
out together.

361.12.text: I didn`t know anything about it.

363.26.text:
Julia is going out with Tim
But...

387.35.text:
So what will this new series
of yours be about

389.75.text:
If you come to the meeting tomorrow,
you`ll find out.

391.85.text: Some of your young fans, boys.

393.89.text: Can we have your autographs, please

398.19.text: What`s it like to be a star

400.50.text: These kids can recognize real talent.

404.47.text: Well, actually, this is for my grandma.

415.98.text:
And the next item is:
Tim`s new series. Tim

420.48.text:
OK. Well the series will be called
"People"...

423.52.text:
...and it will be about people`s
lives...

428.56.text:
...like nurses, shop assistants, bank
managers, housewives.

434.80.text: Won`t that be a bit - ordinary

437.80.text:
No, they`ll be ordinary people, but
with an extraordinary story to tell.

442.14.text:
- How will it work
- It`ll be very simple.

444.74.text:
We`ll interview someone in the studio
about his or her life story.

448.78.text: And will you be the interviewer

450.81.text: I`d like Gary to do it.

454.98.text:
I`d like to direct it. It`ll be a chance for
both of us to try something new.

459.09.text:
- Gary
- I think it`s an excellent idea.

465.36.text:
So, who have we got for the first
programme

468.36.text:
It`s this woman here - Samantha
Richmond. She`s a waitress.

475.34.text:
She got married on her sixteenth
birthday.

478.24.text:
She and her boyfriend ran
away to Gretna Green...

483.05.text:
Sounds interesting.
Are they still married

486.32.text:
Yes, they are.
They`ve got five children now.

489.28.text: Here`s a photo of the family.

492.69.text:
If you do that again,
I`ll go back to my desk.

495.36.text: OK. OK. I promise I`ll behave.

498.13.text:
Good. Now there`s a lot more
about Samantha Richmond.

520.28.text:
What time will this woman be here,
Julia It`s already twenty past two.

523.52.text: I`m sure she`ll be here soon.

525.65.text:
Excuse me. There`s a message on
my answerphone for Julia...

533.56.text:
I was out of the office all morning
at a meeting.

536.33.text: Anyway, she says she`s very sorry...

537.97.text:
...but she can`t come this afternoon
because one of her children is ill.

540.04.text: Oh dear, I hope it`s nothing serious.

543.87.text:
We haven`t got an interview.
That`s serious, isn`t it

548.21.text:
Well, if she can`t do it, we`ll just
have to find someone from here.

551.31.text:
Well, it can`t be me,
because I`m the interviewer.

557.85.text: Anyway, it needs to be someone ordinary.

579.98.text:
Our guest this evening is Sean Casey -
a cameraman here at Apex TV.

584.95.text:
Tell me something about
your early life, Sean.

588.05.text: Well, I was born in Ireland...

591.89.text:
...but my parents moved to England
when I was still a baby...

597.36.text: We were quite a big family - seven kids.

600.06.text:
I didn`t do very well at school
and I left when I was sixteen.

606.07.text: What did you do after school

609.54.text: I got a job in a furniture factory.

616.48.text:
But in my free time I played
the bass guitar...

621.65.text:
And we got a few good gigs,
so I gave up my job...

624.72.text: ...and went on the road with the band.

630.93.text:
...but we played with some famous
bands...

640.37.text:
I remember one night in Las Vegas,
I was in a bar with U2.

643.81.text: They`re great guys - loads of fun.

646.68.text: Well, we were in this bar and...

656.12.text:
Evening, Sean. We watched you on TV
last night. You were very good.

665.86.text:
The kids wanted to watch some quiz
programme on the other channel.

680.54.text: Look out, boys, some more of your fans.

683.05.text: I`ll just get my pen out.

689.08.text:
Can we have your autograph, please,
Mr Casey

690.85.text: We saw you on TV last night.

695.86.text:
Did you really play with
all those big bands

734.93.text:
Here you are.
I`m going to put my feet up.

745.41.text:
Talking of families,
are you working this weekend

749.88.text:
I`m going to my parents`
for the weekend.

751.85.text: Would you like to come over on Sunday

757.52.text:
Why don`t you come over about three
and stay for dinner in the evening

760.32.text: OK. Oh, how do I get there

764.16.text: No! I`ve got my personal organizer.

767.63.text:
The easiest way is to take
the London Road to Kingston.

771.40.text:
There`s a big Asda supermarket just
before you get to the centre of Kingston.

776.04.text:
You go past Asda and take the first
turning on the right.

779.94.text: There`s a post office on the corner.

784.71.text:
Go down there till you come to
the second set of traffic lights.

789.12.text:
Turn left there and you`ll see a pub
called the Black Bull on the right.

794.96.text:
Turn right and Gloucester Avenue is the
third road on the left.

801.70.text:
Turn right by the Black Bull
and third left. 29. Got it.

823.02.text:
Morning, dear.
Do you want some breakfast

829.22.text: Do you have to do that now

831.49.text: You said you wanted it mending.

833.26.text:
- Are we going shopping today
- No, not today.

835.93.text: Do you remember old Mrs Burns

837.87.text:
I`m taking her to stay
with her daughter this morning.

841.67.text:
In one of those little roads
near King George Square.

846.14.text:
It`s more convenient on Sunday
mornings anyway...

860.19.text:
When I was driving home yesterday,
I saw these two kids.

863.89.text:
They were running out of a newsagent`s
and the owner was running after them.

867.90.text:
The kids ran right in front of
my car and I nearly hit them.

871.37.text: But that wasn`t the worst thing.

873.24.text:
When they turned round,
do you know what

894.09.text:
A robbery at a jeweller`s shop
in King George Square.

905.67.text:
Oh, there`s another police car.
I wonder what`s happening.

911.44.text:
Oh dear, there`s nowhere to park.
Well, I`ll just stop here.

927.29.text:
Turn right here.
That`ll be the quickest way.

949.28.text:
Come on!
You`re blocking the street.

986.21.text:
Well, when we got there, I couldn`t find
anywhere to park...

990.45.text:
...so I stopped in the
middle of the street.

992.82.text:
While I was helping Mrs Burns
out of the car...

998.36.text:
...and the driver of the car beeped his
horn at me.

1005.30.text: Poor old Mrs Burns can`t move very fast.

1008.34.text:
So while we were walking to her door,
the young man started shouting at us.

1015.54.text:
And then he grabbed the suitcases
from the car...

1017.75.text:
...and he just dumped them on the
pavement.

1021.48.text:
But, you know, I`m sure I`ve seen him
somewhere before.

1037.63.text:
It isn`t usually as busy as that on a
Sunday, is it, dear

1052.48.text: Excuse me. I`d like a word with you!

1062.09.text: Do you two know each other

1064.46.text:
Well, this is the rude young man
that I was telling you about.

1073.27.text: Oh dear. Mum, Dad. This is Tim.

1101.60.text:
Yes, Mother, if I have time
I`ll try to go shopping at lunchtime.

1108.87.text:
No, I won`t buy any pears,
I know you don`t like them.

1113.71.text: Now, have we got any coffee

1116.31.text:
Well, go and look and
then ring me back.

1130.13.text:
Oh, I`m sorry.
I was expecting another call.

1133.76.text:
What can I do for you
Yes, I have seen the programme.

1143.71.text:
No. No, I don`t think
the programmes are too violent.

1147.44.text: I`m afraid I can`t agree with that.

1160.02.text:
Tim, have you done that programme
about the health farm yet

1165.99.text:
We`re still looking for someone
to go there...

1168.16.text:
...so that we can film their
experiences.

1170.06.text:
I`ve always wanted to go
to a health farm.

1172.90.text: But you`re already fit and healthy...

1174.87.text:
...and we need someone
who`s unfit and stressed out.

1178.57.text:
Stupid man! Rebecca,
have those tapes arrived

1183.38.text:
I`m afraid they won`t be here
till next week.

1191.25.text:
He`s gone to Rio and he
won`t be back till Monday.

1212.24.text:
Yes, I`ll get some coffee.
What

1216.61.text:
No, Mother, I haven`t hidden your
glasses.

1220.28.text:
No, I can`t come home
and look for them.

1258.22.text:
Welcome to Westland Manor Health
and Fitness Centre, Mrs McKay.

1261.79.text:
My name`s Celine, and I`m your
personal consultant.

1265.33.text:
- Have you ever stayed here before
- No, I haven`t.

1268.33.text:
- And how long will you be with us
- About a week.

1271.20.text:
I see. Well, first we`ll do some
of our regular tests...

1274.34.text:
...and then we can work out your
personal fitness programme.

1277.24.text: So would you like to follow me

1291.69.text:
...and Celine has worked out a
programme for you.

1293.72.text: Now it`s time for your evening meal.

1295.76.text: Meal You call this a meal

1298.59.text:
A bit of lettuce, a few nuts
and some fruit.

1301.70.text:
They won`t let me have any biscuits or
ice cream or chocolate.

1305.47.text: Can you have any wine or beer

1307.77.text:
I can`t even have a cup of tea or coffee.
This is my drink.

1313.78.text:
I used to be a war correspondent,
you know...

1318.35.text:
...but I always had a good meal
at the end of the day...

1320.95.text:
...with meat and cheese - not this,
this rabbit food.

1325.05.text: And cut! That was great, Martha.

1330.56.text:
Right. Where shall we go for a meal
I`m starving.

1333.73.text: Let`s try that pub down the road.

1335.90.text:
I fancy a nice big steak
and a plateful of chips.

1354.51.text:
It`s nine-thirty and Martha is starting
her exercise programme in the gym.

1361.36.text:
That`s it. Swing those arms.
Swing those arms. Good!

1424.52.text:
OK, another ten minutes
and it`s time for lunch...

1427.92.text:
...and then at half past two we`re
going jogging.

1431.26.text:
Jogging I`ve never been
jogging in my life!

1435.33.text: Oh, how did you talk me into this, Tim

1460.25.text: I used to play with this band, you know.

1462.26.text:
Oh, yes Do you want some more
French fries I`ve had enough.

1495.46.text: So, Martha. How do you feel

1502.66.text:
I have done some
difficult things in my life.

1507.53.text:
I`ve slept in airports, in fields, even
in the street.

1512.54.text:
I`ve travelled for three days on a
camel.

1520.81.text: But this - this is just too much.

1525.75.text:
And what`s the next thing on your
programme

1528.96.text: The next thing on my programme

1531.69.text:
You`ll see. First, I think
I`ll make a phone call.

1593.22.text: How about going to the theatre

1596.92.text: Waiting for Godot. I`d like to see that.

1603.06.text:
No, I`m working on Tuesday and
Wednesday evening this week.

1608.94.text:
All right. Are you going
to get the tickets

1612.34.text: Yes. You forgot them last time.

1614.68.text:
I couldn`t help it. A job came up
at the last minute.

1617.38.text: Hmm. I`ve heard that story before.

1624.28.text: Aren`t you going to your aerobics class

1626.32.text:
Not this week.
The instructor`s hurt her knee.

1630.39.text:
Yes, we`re going to the theatre to see
Waiting for Godot.

1632.83.text:
- What`s the time
- Ten past seven.

1635.03.text: Oh no. I`m going to be late.

1637.10.text: Tim`ll already be at the theatre by now.

1644.34.text: Rebecca It`s Tim. Is Julia there

1651.11.text:
I`m sorry, Tim.
I`ll be with you in ten minutes.

1654.65.text:
Well, um, I`m not at the theatre
actually.

1658.32.text:
I`m afraid something`s come up
and I`ve got to deal with it.

1661.09.text:
Oh, that`s wonderful! So what am
I going to do with the tickets

1664.76.text:
I don`t know. I`m sorry but I have to go.
Bye.

1682.08.text:
This is the third time he`s done
something like this.

1684.88.text: Last time he forgot to get the tickets.

1687.18.text:
The time before that his
jeep had a flat tyre.

1690.62.text: Do you fancy going to the theatre

1693.49.text:
Ooh, yes. I`ve always wanted to see
Waiting for Godot.

1696.46.text:
Well, it`ll be better than waiting for
Tim!

1702.80.text:
Hi. Do you mind if I join you
Oh, here comes the worker.

1709.74.text: Did you go to see that play

1711.51.text:
Yes, thanks. It was very good, wasn`t it,
Rebecca

1716.18.text: Look, I`m sorry I couldn`t make it.

1717.94.text: Work comes first every time, eh, Tim

1721.15.text:
I hope you`re not going to do
anything like this tomorrow night.

1730.26.text:
...I`ve agreed to stand in
for Pete Riley tomorrow...

1732.36.text:
...so I probably won`t be free till
about nine thirty.

1736.13.text:
Would you mind going on
your own and I`ll meet you there

1739.30.text: Oh, all right. But don`t be too late.

1749.01.text:
But there was nobody else
to do the interview.

1752.98.text: "I hear you`ve got a new bloke, Julia"

1754.85.text:
"Where`s your new boyfriend, Julia
Is he here"

1761.46.text:
It`s not funny. You wouldn`t like it if
I stood you up.

1765.86.text:
But it`s my job.
You know what it`s like.

1768.30.text:
I can`t help it if something important
comes up.

1770.70.text:
Something important
So I`m not important

1775.07.text:
There are other things in life besides
work, you know.

1778.44.text:
I`ve got a job, too,
but I`m not a slave to it.

1781.17.text:
But you, you`d miss your own wedding
if "something important" came up.

1787.51.text:
Well, I`m fed up with it, Tim, and I`m
not going to put up with it any more.

1792.79.text: It won`t happen again. I promise.

1811.97.text: Are you doing anything this evening

1814.41.text:
I`m having dinner with Julia
and her parents.

1816.78.text: And this time I`m not going to be late.

1824.92.text:
We`re getting reports of a serious fire
at the Southgate furniture factory.

1828.29.text: We haven`t got any more details yet...

1830.16.text:
...but we`ll bring them to you as soon
as we get them.

1832.56.text:
The Southgate place. That`s about
fifteen minutes from here.

1835.90.text: But what about your dinner with Julia

1838.13.text: That`s not till half past eight.

1845.77.text: That traffic light`s going to turn red.

1884.11.text:
But the police don`t arrest
people for speeding.

1893.19.text:
Resisting arrest
I don`t believe this.

1895.82.text:
Just one question, Sean. Why was he
speeding in the first place

1912.21.text:
Anyway, the Prime Minister asked:
"So are we waiting for Frederick"

1917.61.text:
And Martha said: "I hope not. He`s going
to be in China till next week."

1923.85.text:
So... Blimey!
Where did you spend the night

1930.06.text:
- Don`t talk to me, Tim.
- But I...

1932.39.text:
I don`t want anything more
to do with you.

1951.48.text:
I`ve got two tickets to see
Romeo and Juliet tomorrow.

1956.72.text:
What would you say if
I asked you to come with me

1963.02.text:
What would I say, Gary I`d say
"Thank you. I`d love to go."

2003.40.text:
Every day, millions of tons of rubbish
are produced.

2006.53.text: We throw our rubbish into the dustbin.

2015.11.text: We`ll have to do that bit again. Give me another can.

2028.09.text:
Every day, millions of tons
of rubbish are produced.

2030.92.text: We throw our rubbish into the dustbin.

2033.41.text:
It`s collected and taken away.
But what happens to it then

2036.90.text:
Some things, like bottles, cans,
and paper will be recycled.

2042.54.text:
But most of it will be dumped
in places like this.

2045.67.text: This is the landfill site at Westbridge.

2048.46.text: It was first used ten years ago...

2050.54.text:
...and it was expected to last for
thirty or forty years.

2053.71.text:
But now it`s - um.
Oh damn. Cut.

2060.59.text:
It`s OK. I think we`ll be able
to edit that out and...

2063.36.text: No. This is going to be done properly.

2065.53.text:
We`ll have to start again
from the beginning.

2068.46.text: We haven`t got any more cans.

2071.06.text: Then I`ll just have to use one of these.

2078.27.text:
Every day, millions of tons
of rubbish are produced.

2081.54.text: We throw our rubbish into the dustbin...

2096.49.text:
Have I got an appointment with
Frederick now

2100.96.text:
He`s in Moscow. I can get him
on his mobile, if you want.

2105.50.text:
What on earth is
the matter with Julia

2108.14.text:
I had to tell her something
three times.

2111.17.text:
Haven`t you heard
She and Tim have split up.

2114.01.text:
And Sean says that
Tim`s just the same.

2118.48.text:
They had to film something ten times
this morning...

2124.72.text:
I know. And Julia hasn`t
smiled for days.

2127.59.text:
Well, you can`t work
with people like that.

2130.76.text:
I`ve seen it too many times
and it always causes problems.

2135.70.text: We`ll have to do something about it.

2151.18.text: I`m sorry about this morning, Sean.

2153.48.text: It`s all right. Is it Julia

2156.18.text:
I`ve tried to explain, but she just
won`t listen.

2158.62.text:
I`m sure you`ll be able
to sort things out.

2161.15.text:
Maybe. But she`s going to have to
make the first move. She broke it off.

2165.13.text:
Look. She`ll have to come past here
when she leaves.

2168.36.text: Why don`t you just say hello to her

2171.03.text:
That isn`t too difficult, is it
Same again

2179.74.text:
Why should I make
the first move It was all his fault.

2182.94.text: You don`t have to do anything really.

2184.71.text:
He`s over there. Just say hello to him
when you leave.

2187.35.text: Maybe. Anyway, I`m going now. Bye.

2201.19.text:
Are you still OK for Romeo and Juliet
tonight

2203.53.text: What Oh, er, I suppose so.

2206.80.text:
Great. I`ll pick you up
about quarter to seven

2223.45.text:
Just two minutes to go
and it`s still one-one.

2226.09.text:
Legrand. Anderson. Panini.
Can he do anything

2232.46.text:
What a goal! It`s 2-1 with less than a
minute on the clock.

2268.56.text: Julia. I`m sorry. Please forgive me.

2290.98.text: Are you OK  You were miles away.

2293.29.text:
I was just thinking about something.
Nothing important.

2296.59.text: Well, here we are. Home again.

2305.13.text:
Thank you for this evening, Gary.
I enjoyed the play.

2310.00.text:
Aren`t you going to ask me
in for a cup of coffee

2314.84.text:
No, Gary. It`s late and I won`t be able to
get up in the morning.

2323.38.text:
Oh, sweet Julia. Just one kiss
for your poor Romeo.

2326.65.text:
- Don`t be silly.
- Ow! My ankle!

2342.20.text: Will you be able to drive

2417.31.text: Oh, I`m sorry. I`m working today.

2421.11.text: No, it`s all right. I can change that.

2424.15.text:
No, really. What time do you get to
London

2429.69.text:
Ten forty-five. OK. I`ll be there.
See you later.

2453.91.text:
Sorry to bother you so early,
but I`ve got a bit of a problem.

2456.88.text: Can you cover for me today

2475.54.text:
- What are you doing
- I`ve just seen Tim.

2478.67.text: I thought he was going in late today...

2480.51.text: ...but he seemed to be in a hurry.

2482.31.text:
I suppose "something important"
has come up.

2484.81.text: How was your date with Gary

2499.49.text:
- Lovely to see you, too, Tim.
- But what are you doing here

2502.43.text:
I`ve got an interview next week
for a new job.

2504.80.text: Why didn`t you let me know before

2506.70.text:
I didn`t know myself until yesterday,
and all the flights were fully booked.

2509.80.text: I was lucky to get this one.

2511.61.text: Anyway, I wanted to give you a surprise.

2515.68.text: Now, what would you like to do today

2518.21.text:
Oh, I don`t know really.
I`m a bit tired.

2527.75.text:
Where is it Oh, I put it here yesterday,
I know I did. Oh no!

2540.67.text: It`s OK. I`ll be all right.

2543.17.text:
You`ll have to sort things out with him,
you know.

2545.04.text: You can`t go on like this.

2547.14.text: Do you want me to talk to him

2549.14.text:
No, I`ll go and see him when we get
home - if he`s there.

2553.38.text: Martha said he`s taking a few days off.

2585.28.text: The man phoned again later on.

2587.15.text:
So I said, if I were you, I`d write
a letter to the Managing Director...

2606.47.text: I`ve had a really nice day.

2608.94.text:
Just a minute, Denise.
I`ll introduce you to my neighbours.

2613.77.text: I feel a bit tired now - jet lag.

2615.88.text:
OK. We can call in at the wine bar
tomorrow evening.

2624.38.text: Can I have a word, please

2627.19.text: Of course, Julia. What`s the problem

2630.89.text: Can I move to another department

2634.26.text:
A transfer But why
You`re doing so well here.

2641.10.text:
Tim, I suppose.
Haven`t you two made it up yet

2647.51.text: But you were made for each other.

2650.44.text:
When you get to my age
you can see these things.

2656.45.text: Well, if you really want a transfer...

2659.29.text:
...I`ll talk to Frederick when he gets
back from Russia.

2662.42.text: But I`ll be sorry to lose you.

2669.53.text: I`ll just go to the loo.

2680.54.text: It didn`t take you long to find one.

2682.31.text:
It didn`t take me long
What about you

2684.81.text:
Last night you were kissing and
cuddling him in the street.

2689.98.text:
You were - I went out to get a pizza and
when I was coming back, I saw you.

2694.36.text:
I wasn`t cuddling Gary. He had fallen
over and twisted his ankle.

2698.07.text:
I was helping him. Isn`t that right,
Gary

2706.40.text: I`m back. Are these your friends

2711.40.text:
This is, um, Gary, Sean,
Rebecca and Julia.

2722.50.text:
Your sister Your sister
Why didn`t you say

2726.48.text: You didn`t give me a chance.

2728.37.text: There`s a free table over there.

2730.28.text: So, what are you doing here
